Dear Mr. Gonzalez:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
January 30, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of
all of the following information prior to employment or
at the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior
to employment from persons unrelated to the
employee and which are less than 12 months old.
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency,
Canadian province, or other country where the
2

person usually resides or has resided in the
previous 5 years.
One of four new employee files did not have 3 dated references completed within
12 months prior to hire. The staff member worked for another program within
Bethany Christian Services and her references were completed in 2021.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of
all of the following information prior to employment or
at the time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department
of human services, the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial agency, or equivalent
agency in the country where the person
usually resides, that the person has not been
determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse
or child neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to the
start of employment and every 12 months
thereafter.
One of four new employee files had a central registry check completed over 30
days prior to hire. The employee had a CWL-4624 completed on 6/16/23 and a
CWL-1929 dated 6/18/23, which are both over 30 days prior to her hire date of
8/6/23.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to employment,
that each employee and volunteer who has contact
with residents 4 or more hours per week for more
than 2 consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1 year period
before employment and shall be verified every 1
year after the last verification or prior to the
expiration of the current verification.
3

One of four new employees did not complete a TB test prior to hire.
CCI Rule 400.4116 Chief Administrator; responsibilities.
(1) An agency shall assign the chief administrator
responsibility for the on-site day-to-day operation of
the institution and for ensuring compliance with
these rules.
Chief Administrator did not monitor CAP expectations from the facility's 2023
renewal audit or the approved CAP from SIR2023C0000713. Based on
information received via email from Program Director on 2/1/24, action steps listed
in the facility's 2023 renewal audit were not implemented. On 2/2/24, Chief
Administrator reported the previous program director was responsible for handling
and overseeing the CAP dissemination and he's not sure how she did that or who
she provided the information to. Chief Administrator reported the implementation
of the CAP for SIR2023C0000713 was the Unit Supervisor’s responsibility. He
reported another Branch Director, the Unit Supervisor and Human Resources
determined how to best handle the supervision issues raised and Chief
Administrator “was informed”. Chief Administrator reported he didn't have "direct
hands-on contact" regarding ensuring the CAP from the facility’s 2023 renewal
audit or the CAP from SIR2023C0000713 were implemented.
In addition, the Chief Administrator was unaware a supervisor of direct care
workers was hired on 12/26/23 who does not meet the qualifications of the
position, and a variance was not requested prior to hire. The Chief Administrator
reported another Branch Director was overseeing the facility and the hiring
process. The Chief Administrator is not aware of the day-to-day operations of the
facility and has not completed tasks to ensure the facility's compliance with
licensing rules.
C CI Rule 400.4120 Supervisor of direct care workers; qualifications.
(1) A supervisor of direct care workers must have 1 of
the following:
• (1) A supervisor of direct care workers must have
1 of the following:

experience in a child caring institution.
4

One of one supervisor of direct care workers does not have any experience
working in a CCI and, therefore, does not meet the requirement of the rule. The
facility did not request a variance prior to hire.
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of
the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time
between the variable interval checks shall not exceed
fifteen minutes.
Twelve observation/room check logs were reviewed for December 2023 and
thirteen observation/room check logs were reviewed for January 2024. Out of the
twenty-five logs reviewed, nineteen were for third shift. Out of the 542 documented
room checks completed on the logs reviewed for 3rd shift, only 267 checks were
completed in variable intervals not to exceed 15 minutes (49%). Of note, on
12/4/23, only three room checks were documented and there were no checks
documented after 12:33 am.
Repeat Violation Established
SIR2023C0000713, CAP approved 11/8/23.

(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person

CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the
new location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the
services provided while in residence, including
medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that
remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility
after discharge.
7

(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental
follow up that is needed, have been reviewed
with the resident and with the parent and with the
responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom
the resident was discharged.
Two of two closed youth files reviewed lacked a discharge plan covering
subsections (a) through (f).

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The agency was reminded a "new hire" consists of employees not hired
under the facility's license even if they already work for Bethany Christian
Services, which includes promotions within the overarching agency of
Bethany Christian Services. Therefore, a new hire protocol should be
established for employees who fall under these categories to ensure all
licensing rules for new hires are complied with.
• The facility should be completing quarterly file reviews (as established in
the 2023 Renewal audit CAP) to ensure compliance with licensing rules,
specifically treatment plan signatures by youth, workers, and supervisors.
• The facility should develop a process to ensure discharge plans are being
completed for discharged youth. This should include a process for
providing a summary on unplanned discharges.
8

• Variance requests must be submitted and approved prior to hiring or
promoting a candidate into a position. It is not acceptable to submit a
variance after hiring has already occurred. If there are questions as to
whether someone meets the qualifications required in licensing rules, the
facility can clarify with their assigned DCWL Consultant prior to hire.
• The current Assistant Supervisor signed a job description upon hire stating
she would serve as the Unit Supervisor in their absence. However, the
Assistant Supervisor does not meet the requirements of Rule
400.4120(1)(a) as she does not have experience working in a child caring
institution. Therefore, the agency was asked to alter the job description to
remove that language. They provided the updated, signed job description
on 2/1/24.
• The facility has stated more than once the reasons for some of these non-
compliances are because they are meeting ORR requirements, but not
considering licensing requirements. To maintain licensing for this facility
under the State of Michigan, licensing rules must be followed regardless of
any contractor requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• It is recommended the description on the observation log to be updated.
The form can be confusing as it notes “On school days visual checks begin
at 9pm and continue until 7am the following morning. On non-school days
observation will continue until 9am.” When youth are asleep or otherwise
outside of direct supervision of staff, staff must perform variable interval,
eye-on checks of the youth. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed 15 minutes.
• Audit lists for closed youth should not be reflective of their placement
history. For example, if a youth is AWOL for 3 days, the youth should not
show up as “closed” when AWOL started and admitted when they return
from AWOL. If the youth was not officially discharged from the facility, they
are not considered to be a new admission per licensing rules when they
return.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had one CAP as a result of their 2023 Renewal audit. During the 2023
renewal audit, violations were found for dental exams, physical exams, initial
9

treatment youth plan signatures, initial treatment plan supervisor signatures,
updated treatment plan youth signatures, updated treatment plan supervisor
signatures, criminal background checks for staff prior to employment, maintaining a
full employee file, and staff orientation prior to assuming duties. The facility made
progress with compliance with dental exams, physical exams, and criminal
background checks for staff prior to employment. Technical assistance is being
provided surrounding the facility having a complete employee file, as the
recommendations made during the Renewal audit were not fully implemented. Out
of the nine violations in the 2023 renewal audit, there are five repeat violations for
the current interim audit. The facility did not implement the quarterly file reviews
listed as an action step on the 2023 Renewal CAP. All of the quarterly file review
sheets located in the files were blank. On 2/2/24, Chief Administrator reported the
previous program director was responsible for handling and overseeing CAP
dissemination and he wasn't sure how she did that or who she provided the
information to.
The second CAP was a result of SIR2023C0000713 (dated 10/4/23). The violations
for SIR2023C0000713 were regarding falsification of documentation related to
youth interval checks and staff not completing random interval checks on youth as
required. The facility has made progress regarding falsification of documentation as
the facility implemented a new computer system to document the checks, which
requires staff to document their checks electronically. As a result, the system
automatically enters the time the staff completed the checks when they enter their
notes. In addition, random checks have been completed by the supervisor and
program director to ensure random interval checks are being documented at the
appropriate times as verified by camera footage. Unfortunately, the facility has not
improved in the area of compliance with interval checks being completed as
required per the rule.
Financial Overview
After a review of the facility's budget and financial audit, there were no financial
concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
10

Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted staff turnover has been the greatest challenge and
impediment to contract and licensing compliance. CA stated with high turnover,
they lack the stability and knowledge of veteran staff. He noted this facility has
undergone staffing changes for the program director, case management
supervisor, program supervisor and case manager during the period of review. CA
noted a couple focus areas emerged because of the 2023 renewal audit. Those
areas included a regular review of policies and overall contract compliance being
made an integral part of regular supervision, additional trainings for case managers
and youth specialists, and human resources reviewing/increasing wages for youth
specialists and case managers. CA noted the increase in review of expectations
and additional trainings reportedly were having a positive impact on the staff and
program. However, the resignation of the unit supervisor and case management
supervisor impacted training efforts. CA noted they are going to continue to work to
stabilize staffing, increasing the longevity of staffing and increasing expectations of
supervisors holding their direct reports more accountable for licensing rules. CA
reported bi-weekly team meetings and monthly direct care staff meetings will
continue to occur throughout the year. During the meetings, staff will review policies
and procedures, receive specialized training related to working with refugee youth,
make enhancement to facility programming, and ensure high quality service
provision at all levels. The program has also received approval for, and will be
posting, a Quality Assurance position that will assist supervisors and the director in
all aspects of daily monitoring and evaluation of the practices outlined.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported new supervisors have led to some adjustments, both good and bad.
Staff reported it's difficult to get used to new expectations and standards for each
new leader. However, staff report communication and expectations are clearer, and
they feel there is more accountability. Staff feel the new supervisors are invested in
learning about the program, rules, and policies. Staff also feel the supervisors are
open to ideas and feedback regarding changes to current practices. Staff feel they
have enough support and training to complete their positions. Supervisors report
staff are great at communicating through TEAMS. Supervisors both reported they
are trying to learn about the staff and program since they are new. Supervisors feel
staff are very invested in helping them learn, the program, and youth.
Youth reported they feel safe at the facility. Two out of three youth reported they felt
they could go to staff if they needed something or had any concerns. One youth
reported she did not feel comfortable because she was new and didn't know staff
well enough yet. They all reported they like the food and there is enough food
provided. They all reported staff are nice to them. The only frustration expressed
from youth was an inability for any of them to do independent outings right now.
They reported they did not understand why independent outings were cancelled
and want more freedom. This issue was discussed with supervisor and
administration.
11

Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility occurred on 1/30/24 and there were no safety
concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
